item.title: Data science panel questions
item.description: I was on a panel the other day talking about data science careers (I guess there will be a link to it somewhere at some point, I‚Äôll share it when I see it) and they‚Äôve sent some questions out after the event because they didn‚Äôt get through them all.

item.title: RAP; a 10 year journey
item.description: I found the earliest possible reference that I ever made to RAP in a document, part of an evaluation report I submitted nearly 10 years ago.

item.title: Data science for dummies (Goldacre)
item.description: Building your own tools for data science is a pretty fundamental concept, and I think it‚Äôs fair to say that it‚Äôs totally alien to most NHS bosses.

item.title: We need more than "black box"; systems (Goldacre)
item.description: The system should be cautious around imagining that it can push away the challenge of TREs ‚Äì and all work with NHS data ‚Äì by procuring ‚Äòblack box‚Äô services.

item.title: The prevalence of code sharing (Goldacre)
item.description: Another greatest hit from the Goldacare report, in the section on open working, ‚ÄúThe prevalence of code sharing‚Äù (all material reused under OGL)

item.title: The Goldacre review- greatest hits
item.description: I absolutely love the Goldacare review, I really can‚Äôt praise it enough, and I will be doing a lot of work based on it in the coming weeks and months looking at it from the perspective of my own Trust and, (with others) from the perspective of my ICS, and NHS-R.

item.title: In defence of the ordinary
item.description: I think this might be a general cultural problem, but I notice it a lot in my field of healthcare analytics.

item.title: In defence of looking at jobs
item.description: Nobody should ever have to apologise for looking at jobs, however settled they are.

item.title: In defence of holiday working
item.description: This might be a little bit controversial, this post. If you hate it please don‚Äôt be offended, it‚Äôs just my opinion.

item.title: In defence of eating
item.description: One weird thing in remote/ pandemic times is that people have started turning their cameras off when they eat.

item.title: In defence of dashboards
item.description: I‚Äôve had lively debates about dashboards with various people, including someone in my own team, and somebody on Twitter just mentioned that dashboards are often not used (this blog post will be my response to this tweet, not the first time I‚Äôve answered a tweet with a blog and very on brand for me üòâ).

item.title: Make statistics sexy
item.description: I‚Äôve been enjoined to make statistics sexy. It‚Äôs really taking root in my brain.

item.title: Data saves lives- and so does open code
item.description: I‚Äôm reading data saves lives. And look, it‚Äôs that thing that I say all the time, that I have pinned on my Twitter profile, the thing I‚Äôve heard time and time again for a decade that everybody just stands around nodding at and nothing actually changes.

item.title: Pay and reward
item.description: I‚Äôm reading No Rules Rules, the Netflix management book. It‚Äôs really good, lots of interesting stuff in there about doing things differently and although clearly there‚Äôs a lot I can‚Äôt do in the NHS, there are lessons in there for sure.

item.title: Graphs > tables
item.description: One phenomenon that I find very strange in the NHS (and elsewhere, probably, I‚Äôve never worked anywhere else) is the obsession people have with having tables of numbers instead of graphs.

item.title: Stop punishing people with data
item.description: Any observed statistical regularity will tend to collapse once pressure is placed upon it for control purposes

item.title: Shoddy data
item.description: You know, naming no names because I‚Äôll get in trouble but someone somewhere has paid for some data from a proprietary vendor and they‚Äôre shipping absolutely unusable garbage data.

item.title: Managing data science teams in the trenches
item.description: We‚Äôre systematically devaluing management and leadership in the analyst space, and I encounter a lot of people who think that a day with no code written is a day wasted.

item.title: What do we want from senior analysts in the NHS?
item.description: I‚Äôve been meaning to write this for ages and I‚Äôve just had a rather silly conversation on Twitter about managers and leaders in the NHS which has inspired me to get on with it.

item.description: From a tweet from my NHS-R buddy John MacKintosh

item.description: We‚Äôre rebuilding our patient experience dashboard at the moment, partly to incorporate some of the work that we‚Äôre doing on text mining and partly to connect it up to other types of information we have like staff experience and clinical outcomes.

item.description: It was my New Year‚Äôs resolution to blog more and that‚Äôs going really well because this is the first blog I‚Äôve done all year and it‚Äôs nearly the end of January.

item.description: We have our patient feedback dashboard in the open where anyone can see what Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust‚Äôs patients are saying about us.

item.description: I work in a small (growing) team of data scientists and we‚Äôre part of a larger analytic unit which has a focus on innovation in analytics (hence us) and public health methods.

item.description: I‚Äôve got a guest piece on the Patient Opinion Blog which is cross-posted below.

item.title: Super easy heatmaps of postcodes
item.description: Whatever I want to do, there are always intrepid explorers who‚Äôve been there and blogged it, and so the satisfaction of my long held desire to get to know more about how Nottinghamshire Healthcare‚Äôs services are spread geographically has been wonderfully expedited by these amazing blog posts.

item.title: Easy tables for publication
item.description: I‚Äôm writing for a journal article today and it‚Äôs the familiar problem of how to export all of the beautiful tables and graphs from LaTeX to Word (using R, of course).

item.title: A joke about R
item.description: I‚Äôm so sorry, I‚Äôve come across an R joke I must share.

item.description: List of R tutorials for beginners.

item.title: Great analogue visualisation
item.description: Perhaps another chapter in the infographics versus data graphics debate, a truly eye-catching visualisation of sugar contents in different drinks.

item.title: Parallelising with R
item.description: I‚Äôve been fitting some generalised linear mixed effects models with 400,000 rows or so and it takes a while even on my quad core 3.

item.title: Quick R tip- making scripts work across OS’s
item.description: Quick thought for newbies to R. I have spent four years loading in data like this

item.title: Dr John Milton – Your days are numbered: Measuring clinical performance in mental health
item.description: Excellent post re: Moneyball and a clinician‚Äôs perspective.

item.description: If you‚Äôre a keen user of the base graphics functionality in R (and you should be) then you‚Äôll love this excellent summary of some of the useful and esoteric options within:

item.title: Because it’s Friday- animated graphs
item.description: I‚Äôve been analysing some data and we‚Äôre a bit unsure, as we often are, as to its quality.

item.title: Visualization series: Insight from Cleveland and Tufte on plotting numeric data by groups
item.description: Wonderful post about visualisation and The Problem with Pie Charts (I found a 3D pie chart in a Joint Strategic Needs Assessment this morning).

item.title: Amazing video- Inventing on principle
item.description: I‚Äôve just seen an amazing video, Brett Victor talking about Inventing on Principle.

item.title: Stupidest pie chart of the year 2011
item.description: I‚Äôve just been looking at the Stupidest bar chart of the year 2011 and I‚Äôve been inspired to submit my Stupidest pie chart of the year 2011.

item.title: New Year’s resolutions
item.description: It‚Äôs that time of year again, so what do I need to keep doing or do differently this year?

item.title: Complex surveys in R
item.description: I carried out what I thought was going to be a very simple piece of work the other day, slicing up some of the questions from a publicly available dataset in order to compare Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust with some other sites based on particular features of interest.

item.title: Quick presentations
item.description: Just a quick one from me today, lots of deadlines colliding, which is handy because that‚Äôs what this post is about.

item.title: Simulating data
item.description: I try to publish as much of my work as I can on the internet, where the people who own the data agree (my little bit of the website is here) but very often I can‚Äôt publish the data because of issues with ongoing projects, other publications, various levels of confidentiality of data, and so on.

item.title: Robin Hood marathon results
item.description: I ran the Robin Hood marathon yesterday in a decent-ish 4 hours and 13 minutes, which is my best yet.

item.title: Misleading means and medians
item.description: Over at this excellent blog there is an interesting discussion about times when means and medians can be deceptive, particularly in the case where two variables with equal means have very different distributions.

item.title: useR day four and beginner’s odfWeave
item.description: I‚Äôm a bit late with the report from the last day of the useR conference, I was very busy Thursday getting home and catching up with the housework on Friday.

item.title: useR day three
item.description: The last post perhaps was a bit over-long on extraneous detail and bits of R-commands that most readers will either know backwards or have no interest in, and today‚Äôs learning sheet is over double the length of yesterday‚Äôs, so let‚Äôs really do one thing I learned today.

item.title: Day 2 of useR
item.description: Well, I said I was going to blog at least one thing I learned at the conference each day, today I‚Äôve learned about 50 million things (yesterday was tutorials so I learned two things well; seen 20 presentations today, posters later).

item.title: useR conference update
item.description: I‚Äôm at the useR! conference so I‚Äôll be blogging every day with at least one thing that I learned.

item.title: How do interest rates affect the way my mortgage is paid off?
item.description: With a baby on the way my wife and I have become very interested in the interest rate on our mortgage, and how it might go up or down, and how that will affect whether we overpay to build up some equity, etc.

item.title: New book- The visual display of quantitative information
item.description: Took delivery of a new book today, Tufte‚Äôs Visual Display of Quantitative Information.

item.description: As always, I‚Äôm late to this party, and wordclouds have come under fire in recent times, e.

item.title: The patient survey: past, present and future
item.description: Within my organisation we have something known as the Service User and Carer Experience Survey, often abbreviated to the SUCE, or in more natural spoken English, the patient survey.

item.title: Welcome to the blog
item.description: Inspired by the many excellent blogs about research, statistics, and computing I have finally decided to set up my own.
